title: VbO2 - heating curve-Kp-decrease V-O2 rxn order

content.question: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about the compounds and reactions of <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a newly discovered nonmetallic element. The following is a complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for <math alttext="V b O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, an oxide of <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom in <math alttext="V b O 2." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: Directions: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions about the compounds and reactions of <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, a newly discovered nonmetallic element. The following is a complete Lewis electron-dot diagram for <math alttext="V b O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, an oxide of <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Identify the hybridization of the valence orbitals of the <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> atom in <math alttext="V b O 2." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

A student investigates the physical properties of <math alttext="V b O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and finds the following graph where thermal energy is added at a constant rate to a sample of <math alttext="V b O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is initially a solid at <math alttext="0 degrees Celsius." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The pressure is held constant at <math alttext="1.00 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> throughout the heating process. (b) The student determines that the specific heat of <math alttext="V b O 2, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="2.0 joules per gram degree Celsius." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mtext> J/</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>g</mtext><mo>·</mo><mtext>°</mtext><mtext>C</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Determine the amount of thermal energy, in <math alttext="joules" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>J</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, that must be added to a <math alttext="5.5 gram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.5</mn><mtext> g</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of <math alttext="V b O 2, liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> to raise the temperature from <math alttext="40 decimal point degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="60 decimal point degrees Celsius." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60.</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Two intervals are marked on the graph where the temperature of the sample remains constant. Given that the sample is heated at a constant rate, explain why <math alttext="delta t sub 2 is greater than delta t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mtext>t</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext> </mtext><mo>></mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msub><mrow><mtext>t</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) The student claims that the intermolecular attractions in liquid <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (boiling point <math alttext="equals 100 degrees Celsius" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>= 100</mtext><mtext> °</mtext><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></math>) are weaker than those in liquid <math alttext="V b O 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. Do you agree or disagree with the student’s claim? Justify your answer in terms of the relative boiling points.

(e) The solid curve below shows the distribution of molecular speeds for a sample of gaseous <math alttext="V b O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="110 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>110</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The student incorrectly sketches the dashed line to show the distribution of <math alttext="V b O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> particles when the temperature decreases to <math alttext="80 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>80</mn><mtext> </mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Explain the student’s error.

The student injects <math alttext="V b, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> into a rigid container at a constant temperature of <math alttext="400 Kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The initial pressure of <math alttext="V b, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="7.0 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>7.0</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the initial pressure of <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is <math alttext="5.5 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5.5</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. <math alttext="V b, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> react to produce <math alttext="V b O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, as represented by the following equation. <math alttext="V b, gas, plus O 2, gas, is in equilibrium with V b O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⇄</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (f) When the system reaches equilibrium, <math alttext="2.5 atmospheres" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn><mtext> atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="V b O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is present in the container. Determine the equilibrium partial pressures of <math alttext="V b, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the container.

(g) What is the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, for the reaction at <math alttext="400 Kelvin?" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> K</mtext><mtext> ?</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(h) The student transfers the equilibrium mixture to a new container with a smaller volume at <math alttext="400 Kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mtext> K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. After equilibrium is re-established, would the mole fraction of <math alttext="V b O 2, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> be less than, equal to, or greater than what it was in the original container? Justify your answer.

To study the kinetics of the reaction, the student runs several trials of the reaction between <math alttext="V b, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data are presented in the following table. Trial Initial <math alttext="molar concentration of O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) Initial <math alttext="molar concentration of V b, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="in molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) Initial Rate (<math alttext="in molar per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>/</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>) 1 0.20 0.20 <math alttext="8.0 times 10 to the negative 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>8.0</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 2 0.20 0.30 <math alttext="1.2 times 10 to the negative 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> 3 0.10 0.30 <math alttext="1.2 times 10 to the negative 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>​ (i) Based on the data, determine the order of the reaction with respect to <math alttext="O 2, gas." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Justify your answer.

(j) The reaction is known to be first order with respect to <math alttext="V b, gas." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using this information and the answer to part (i), write the rate law for the reaction.

The student proposes that the following elementary reaction is the rate-limiting step in a multistep mechanism. <math alttext="V b, gas, plus O 2, gas, react to produce V b O, gas, plus O, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>→</mo><mtext>VbO</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>+</mo><mtext>O</mtext><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> (k) Is the proposed rate-limiting step consistent with the rate law written in part (j)? Justify your answer.

Element <math alttext="V b" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> forms a molecule with formula <math alttext="V b O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>. The following Lewis diagrams represent the <math alttext="V b O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule. (l) A student claims that <math alttext="V b O 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>VbO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> contains all three <math alttext="V b O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Vb</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bonds of equal length. Do you agree or disagree? Justify your answer.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
